awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Maximizing the Expected Value of Engineered  Systems Through Coordinated Verification
awd_abstract_narration:
Verification is a crucial process in the development of complex systems during which engineers build confidence that their system functions as intended. Because resources are limited, engineers must be strategic in the planning and execution of verification activities. Many large engineered systems are composed of parts and subsystems developed by different firms, which complicates system verification. Much of the verification process is reactive rather than proactive and impacted by schedule and budget pressure. This research project will create and evaluate a mathematical framework of incentives as a coordination mechanism among engineering teams during system verification. Individual teams will define their own verification strategies while maximizing the value of the overall system. If successful, this research will benefit the public through increased safety and efficacy of commercial products and public services. It will enable U.S. industry to be more competitive by making system verification more efficient and effective. The project also includes active recruiting and mentoring activities that will advance the interests and skills of women and other underrepresented groups in engineering.

The objective of this research is to mathematically derive value-maximizing system verification strategies for multi-firm systems engineering projects. This method enables computing verification strategies that maximize a firm's objective function, while accounting for the interdependencies between the firms, the components they develop, and the value of the overall system. Moreover, the framework will account for and enable the design of contractual agreements between firms in order to ensure that locally optimal firm verification decisions contribute to the global goal of maximizing system value. To achieve this research objective, mathematical methods from operations research, decision theory, and economics will be combined and advanced into one framework. The mathematical foundations of the research include partially observable Markov decision processes for deriving optimal verification strategies for each firm, multiscale decision theory to mathematically capture the interdependencies between firms, and contract theory to design effective contracts that can implement globally optimal verifications strategies. Studies of engineering projects will provide empirical evidence about these methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the development of mathematical models that capture the dependencies between organizations engaged in the collective development of an engineered system. Specifically, the work addressed the processes and decisions that organizations use and make with respect to verifying that the system is free of errors and does what it is supposed to do before deploying it to operational use. When used at scale, the mathematical models developed with the support of this grant, which are normative in nature, can guide organizations in designing verification strategies. Today, systems engineering practitioners lack methods to design verification strategies that incorporate contract design. This yields verification strategies that are driven by post-negotiations and risky de-scoping actions when under schedule and budget pressure. By improving the design of verification strategies, the public could benefit from increased safety and efficacy of commercial products and public services.

The mathematical models were used to explore the value of using incentives, financial or otherwise, to align the verification activities that the different organizations in a consortium perform with the objective or goal that a customer might have for such a system. These scenarios covered various common organizational arrangements, including vertical integration (a single organization develops the complete system), pseudo-partnerships (multiple organizations work without a hierarchy), and horizontal integration (multiple organizations collectively develop the system following a established hierarchy between the organizations).

The simulations show that incentives are a valuable mechanism to support the design of verification strategies for engineered systems that are collectively developed by multiple organizations, regardless of their specific organizational arrangements.

The mathematical models, while limited in size as part of this grant, provide a formalism that is unprecedented in the systems engineering community. Whereas the design of verification strategies in current practice relies on qualitative evaluations performed by subject matter experts using their own experience, these mathematical models allow for quantitively assess the merit of different verification strategies on the basis of an agreed upon decision model.

Furthermore, the mathematical models have also increased the accuracy with which verification strategies are modeled. Correction activities are both critical and common in the development of engineered systems. Yet, existing approaches at the time of performing this work, made simplistic assumptions about the effects of correcting a defective system. A single kind of model was used regardless of the nature of the correction activity. With the support of this grant, mathematical models of verification strategies have been expanded to capture the different effects that different correction activities have on the value of the system and the state of the verification process. These have shown to enable the finding of more meritorious verification strategies than when using simplistic models.

The results of this research have been published in archived journals and presented at professional conferences. Furthermore, synthetic datasets and simulation algorithms to apply and solve the mathematical models to different scenarios have been developed.

Finally, this grant has supported the education and research preparation of one post-doctoral researcher, one doctoral student, and one undergraduate researcher from an underrepresented group, as well as the preparation of educational material for graduate coursework.
